retrieval info.text: Giuseppe Fortunino Francesco Verdi was an Italian composer, born on October 1813 and died on January 1901, known for his contributions to opera. He rose from a family of moderate means in Busseto, province of Parma, to dominate the Italian opera scene after the era of fellow composers Gioachino Rossini, Vincenzo Bellini, and Gaetano Donizetti, whose works significantly influenced him. Verdi's early operas demonstrated a sympathy with the Risorgimento movement, which sought the unification of Italy, with the chorus "Va, pensiero" from his early opera Nabucco serving as a representative of these ideals. Verdi also briefly participated as an elected politician. Some of Verdi's most acclaimed works from his 'middle period' are Rigoletto, Il trovatore and La traviata. He is also known for his three late-life masterpieces: his Requiem, Otello, and Falstaff.

retrieval info.text: Ambroise Thomas was a French composer and teacher, known for his operas Mignon (1866) and Hamlet (1868). He was a student at the Conservatoire de Paris and won the Prix de Rome. Thomas pursued a career as an opera composer, completing his first opera in 1837 and twenty further operas throughout his career, focusing on both comic and serious subjects. He was appointed as a professor and later, director at the Conservatoire in 1856 and 1871 respectively. There he modernised the Conservatoire's organisation but was known for his conservative curriculum. His operas were neglected for much of the 20th century but have faced a revival in recent decades.
